awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Conference Support for the Python in Heliophysics Community (PyHC) 2024 Summer School; Boulder, Colorado; May 20-24, 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will provide travel support up to 20+ selected participants to participate in the 2024 Python in Heliophysics Community (PyHC) summer school to be held on May 20-24 at the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP) in Boulder, CO. The PyHC 2024 summer school will provide a platform for attendees to learn more about Open-Source Software (OSS) efforts with the Heliophysics and space physics communities, gain knowledge in working with OSS software projects, and discuss and collaborate on open software packages and techniques.  The project seeks to boost representation of women and other minorities, students, early career and post-doctoral developers and scientists, and potential attendees from smaller institutions.  Digital copies of presentations, tutorials, and demonstrations will be collected and kept online on PyHC’s YouTube channel for public viewing and the material will be stored in the PyHC GitHub repository for public access.   

The PyHC 2024 Summer School will serve as a gathering for the Heliophysics community to come together and learn more on the existing open-source Python software available for their use. Attendees will receive an overview of open-source Python Heliophysics software through the lens of PyHC packages. Topics to be covered include PyHC core package introductions, a look into time, coordinates and SPICE kernels and how PyHC software handles those, a “how to” session for relevant software topics, a panel session where participants submit questions to be answered by the PyHC package developers, interoperability sessions, student group activities leveraging PyHC software, and an introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning in Heliophysics. Summer school participants will work with the NASA HelioCloud platform, providing them with experience on cloud software. Travel award criteria will be developed and vetted by the Summer School organizing committee and will be based on need, relevance, career stage, and equity for considerations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To continue to share Python in Heliophysics Community (PyHC) software capabilities with the larger Heliophysics and space physics communities, core PyHC leadership organized its second summer school, May 20-24, 2024, at LASP in Boulder, CO and online on Zoom. The 2024 summer school leveraged materials from the first summer school, while improving upon them based on feedback from attendees in 2022. This NSF travel support grant was requested for to fund participants to attend onsite for the higher immersion and stronger ability to create meaningful conversations that lead to future work. 

The ability to understand, work with, and create open-source software (OSS) is increasingly important in the era of open science. OSS requires connections with current developers and education. As such, it is important to fund participation in summer schools such as the PyHC 2024 summer school, that are explicitly focused on these kinds of OSS education and collaboration. The summer school gave attendees an overview of open-source Python Heliophysics software through the lens of PyHC packages. Topics included PyHC core package introductions, a look into time, coordinates and SPICE kernels and how PyHC software handles those, a “how to” session for relevant software topics, a panel session where participants submit questions to be answered by the PyHC package developers, interoperability sessions, student group activities leveraging PyHC software, and an introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning in Heliophysics. Summer school participants also had the opportunity to work with the NASA HelioCloud platform, providing them with experience on cloud software used alongside research. This experience was even more enriched by attending on-site, giving attendees the opportunity to connect with the package developers in-person, create professional connections and sources of research software engineering support, and meet other peers in their science field. This would not have been possible without the help of the NSF travel funding.

With this grant, we specifically sought to to boost representation of women and other minorities, students, early career and post-doctoral developers and scientists, and attendees from smaller institutions at the summer school to build stronger and more diverse networks of communication.  In the end, 19 applicants were funded through this award. Statistics of these awardees: 

  • Institutions: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Virginia Tech, University of Texas San Antonio, University of California Los Angeles, University of California Berkeley, University of Illinois Urbana Champaign, University of Texas Arlington, University of Massachusetts Lowell, University of Miami, University of Michigan Ann Arbor, George Mason University, West Virginia University, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, and Stanford University.
  • Career Stage: 8 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students, 4 recent graduates (PhD or highest equivalent terminal degree), and 2 early career persons (within 10 years of receiving their PhD or highest equivalent terminal degree)
